title: 115_hr5856
content: The Act titled "Good Samaritan Charitable Physicians' Services Act of 2018" introduces a deduction for qualified charity care under section 199B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act introduces a deduction for qualified charity care under section 199B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This deduction allows for the reimbursement of qualified charity care provided by direct primary care physicians and other individuals. The deduction for qualified charity care under section 199B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 defines terms like 'unreimbursed Medicare-based value' and 'qualified charity care' for physicians' services provided without expectation of reimbursement to eligible individuals under specific government health plans. The term 'direct primary care physician' refers to a physician who provides primary care to individuals for a periodic subscription fee published on their website. The deduction for physicians' services in a taxable year is limited to the gross receipts attributable to those services. The deduction for physicians' services in a taxable year is limited to the gross receipts attributable to those services. A new item is added to the table of sections for part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 224A. LIMITATION ON LIABILITY FOR VOLUNTEER HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS. SEC. 224A limits liability for physicians providing qualified charity care if not grossly negligent, preempting inconsistent state laws. Definitions include 'physician' and 'attending medical personnel'. The term 'attending medical personnel' refers to individuals licensed to support physicians in providing medical services. The amendments made by this section apply to claims filed for acts or omissions occurring after the enactment of this Act.
